Based on the search results, I found extensive information about Bilbo Baggins' character development in The Hobbit, including various interpretations through LGBTQ+ and neurodivergent lenses. Here's what I discovered:

## Identity and Self-Discovery in The Hobbit

The Hobbit functions as a bildungsroman in which the main character Bilbo Baggins is in the quest of his own identity. The main character, Bilbo Baggins has his own self-discovery through this journey. Metaphorically, Bilbo leaves his previous Baggins-centered identity and starts his quest both in search of treasure and identity.

## Coming of Age and Character Development

Bilbo Baggins undergoes significant character development from a comfort-loving hobbit to a brave adventurer. Initially, Bilbo is depicted as a conventional hobbit, preferring the safety of his home. However, through encounters with trolls, Gollum, and giant spiders, Bilbo discovers his inner courage and resourcefulness. By the end of the story, he has become a respected leader among the dwarves, showcasing bravery, cleverness, and a newfound appreciation for adventure without losing his inherent honesty and loyalty.

Throughout the course of The Hobbit, Bilbo Baggins learns to adapt, problem solve, and finds his own strength and courage. Bilbo has really come into his own, developing his leadership and taking command of difficult situations.

## LGBTQ+ and Queer Readings

### The Word "Queer" in The Hobbit

One of the hobbit's most distinctive traits is that he has a feminine side, inherited from his mother Belladonna Took, which represents something wonderful in him: "Still it is probable that Bilbo, her only son, although he looked and behaved exactly like a second edition of his solid and comfortable father, got something a bit queer in his make-up from the Took side, something that only waited for a chance to come out".

Bilbo, like Tolkien, has undergone such a profound emotional transformation that even his neighbors sense the difference in him. "He was in fact held by all the hobbits of the neighborhood to be 'queer'—except by his nephews and nieces on the Took side, but even they were not encouraged in their friendship by their elders".

### Homoerotic Interpretations

The novel is much more psychologically profound and redolent with sexual symbolism than has been acknowledged by reviewers and Tolkien's biographers. The distinctly homoerotic yearnings of Bilbo Baggins and the psychosexual pathology of Gollum were not discussed by reviewers in 1937 when the book was first published and hailed as a children's classic on both sides of the Atlantic.

The Hobbit on film may spark deeper analysis of the sexuality in the original book in the years to come, and the character of Bilbo Baggins, so long a favorite with readers, may be headed for new life as a gay icon. Tolkien's life story, too, may be revisited by scholars astute enough to understand the author's psychological connection to Bilbo and Frodo, who are in love with other males. Tolkien's sympathetic depiction of the unconventional lives and loves of hobbits takes his readers on journeys that go ever onward, to places yet to be discovered.

### Film Interpretations

Peter Jackson's Hobbit trilogy possesses a certain ludic queerness. Largely eschewing the operatic grandness of The Lord of the Rings — though there are moments of that — this trilogy never takes itself too seriously. Rather it emphasizes the power of pleasure and play — of refusing to play by the rules others have established and lavishing attention on appearances. In doing so, it offers itself up as a more overtly queer send-up response to its predecessor.

There is an invested fan-following around "Baggenshield." This is the inevitable pairing of hobbit Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman) and dwarf Thorin Oakenshield (Richard Armitage). Fans embrace the chemistry between Freeman and Armitage as well as the bond that develops between the two characters over the course of the three films. In fact, I have seen Bilbo referred to as Thorin's "wife," a particular reading that has "queer" written all over it.

## Youth and Development Psychology

The main character, Bilbo Baggins has his own self-discovery through this journey. At the beginning of the novel, he is a domestic character who hesitates to show courage and gets afraid easily. The journey represents a psychological maturation process where Bilbo transitions from an emotionally immature state to one of greater self-awareness and confidence.

It will be displayed how his two natures are at first rather opposing each other and how Bilbo develops so that they complement each other, referring to his internal conflict between his cautious Baggins side and his adventurous Took heritage.

While the search didn't yield specific results about neurodivergent readings of The Hobbit, the various interpretations show how Bilbo's journey of self-discovery resonates with diverse audiences who see aspects of their own experiences reflected in his transformation from an outsider considered "queer" by his community to someone who embraces his unique identity.
